GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

bors r+

```suggestion
def liftToFinsetObj (F : Discrete Î± â¥¤ C) : Finset (Discrete Î±) â¥¤ C where
  obj s := âˆ fun x : s => F.obj x
```

```suggestion
theorem liftToFinsetColimIso_aux (F : Discrete Î± â¥¤ C) {J : Finset (Discrete Î±)} (j : J) :
    Sigma.Î¹ (F.obj Â·.val) j â‰« colimit.Î¹ (liftToFinset.obj F) J â‰«
```

```suggestion
    (fun Î² => by
      simp only [Functor.comp_obj, colim_obj, Functor.comp_map, colim_map, Iso.symm_hom]
```

This is perhaps orthogonal to this PR, but it seems to me that we should instead have `liftToMultiset` and compose with the forgetful functor Multiset => Finset where required. The constructions here should all go through for multisets...

Hmm.. multisets aren't used at all in the category theory library so far, which might or not be because we want swaps of two elements in the diagram to induce an isomorphism and not an equality between the (co)products.

Taking `Fin n` as the  the diagram category does have that effect via `CategoryTheory.Limits.Sigma.reindex`, but taking `Multiset` would destroy it.

I'm not quite sure I follow. Finsets are just multisets without duplicates (in a literal sense), they should have identical behaviour when it comes to swaps. 

The difference arises if you take a product over something like {X, X}, in which the finset version would give (something isomorphic to) X, whereas the multiset version would give X * X.
(Note that `sigmaObj` takes an arbitary family, which, if indexed over `Nat` is also behaving like a `List` and not `Multiset`)

Right, this is why I think `Multiset` is a more sensible choice! It lives exactly between `List` and `Finset`, and the observation that this construction is going from List to Finset is an argument that it could be generalised to instead go from List to Multiset, and later to Finset
Got it, I think you're right. Might be a good refinement for a later PR...
Yes, admittedly this PR was the wrong place to bring up this discussion!

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CategoryTheory): Improve the infrastructure around the `liftToFinset` construction
